entry.title: We Welcome Our Electronic Overlords
entry.content:
“

We are running through the United States with dynamite and rock saws so an algorithm can close the deal three microseconds faster, all for a communications system that no humans will ever see,

”

said Kevin Slavin, Algorithm expert.

I Read a BBC article today - When algorithms control the world. It caught my eye, probably because I miss my fibre connection so much.

I never knew it took more than 60milliseconds to get a trade from the UK to the States, but equally; it will be impressive when it's less!

It was also the quote on the right that interested me. Who is Kevin Slavin and what makes someone an algorithm expert? And why is this term thrown around so much? Is it just to make computer code sound more sexy? Is it only an algorithm when it's a secret? When it's short?

Just wanted to jot something down - as a weblog gitHubPages is cool, but is it a blog if people can't leave feedback/comments easily? Do I need to go here and sign-up for Disqus.

entry.title: UTF-8
entry.content:
Re-capping my knowledge on using UTF-8 in the web stack, with thanks to Jonathan 'Wolf' Rentzsch via John Gruber.

“Iñtërnâtiônàlizætiøn”

The string above is a hard-core word to push through systems.

  • can’t be represented in Latin-1
  • will catch all sorts of hidden failure scenarios.
  • when viewing raw hex, there’s no place for encoding bugs to hide.

For the record, “Iñtërnâtiônàlizætiøn” looks like E2 80 9C 49 C3 B1 74 C3 AB 72 6E C3 A2 74 69 C3 B4 6E C3 A0 6C 69 7A C3 A6 74 69 C3 B8 6E E2 80 9D in UTF-8 in hex.

Wolf provides a few links in the article, mainly to software, but the link to Mo McRoberts - when MySQL encodings go bad is not only a good read about MySQL's default settings generally, but also gives these two UTF-8 symbols “優雅”. What they are I don't know - fingers crossed not anything offensive.

MySQL default Latin-1 will store UTF-8 ☚ that's the problem

UTF-8 stores a whole heap of stuff actually, including all the building block I used as a kid back in the early 80's to make basic animation on the C64. Combined with the new font support in CSS3, I think it might me a good time to work on the project I had planned for my dissertation. The basic premise was this - "You can not only change the look and feel of a website with a typeface, but also it's content and structure." Imagine if all the images for a site were stored in a handcrafted site specific font, with out the font you don't see the desired content.

I'll have to add to this blog post later, have other things to attend to really, I'm sure gitHub Pages uses UTF-8... ☺

entry.title: Lost Mains Power Last Night
entry.content:
So, I went down stairs to make the girlfriend dinner (she works heavy shifts) and found out something new about the house. If you have the oven, tumble dryer, kettle, TV and computers on all at once the main switch trips, awesome!

After fiddling around, working out what order I could do things in, I finished off dinner. After the meal I walked upstairs to find a silence and blank screens. That resulted in me ignoring the issue, reading some more of my book (The Time Travellers Wife) and having an early night.

Early nights only ever lead to one thing, early mornings! So I woke up and got on with work. Work by the way is usually focused around SkipUK. Today I was integrating TradeDoubler Affiliate Marketing, great fun.

Is this blogging for the sake of blogging? Yes. Oh and by the way, whilst writting this - got some great news - The girlfriend no longer has to work shifts forever, she landed a secondment and is working a 9-5 for 12months, finally a social life!

Anyway, back to the grindstone, lunch break over.

entry.title: I turn to GitHub as a possible publishing platform
entry.content:
I will blog, I will blog, I will blog...

I need a voice, I have remained silent for too long.

My current blog dea.n-howe.com has had me tinkering and tweaking for ages, the last delay was due to wanting code syntax high-lighting - for blog posts I haven't even written!

Things I need to look up....

  • Gollum: A simple, Git-powered wiki with a sweet API and local frontend.
  • Jekyll: A simple, blog aware, static site generator (used for this site).
  • God: Ruby process monitoring framework with easy extensibility.
  • Grit: Object oriented Ruby bindings for Git (used by GitHub).
  • Ernie: Ruby/Erlang Hybrid BERT-RPC server.
  • ProxyMachine: Layer 7 routing proxy in Ruby with Event Machine.
  • Primer: JavaScript based Flash-like API layered on top of Canvas.
  • Chronic: Ruby natural language date/time
